questions.question: A group of similar cells along with intercellular substances performing a specific function is called:
questions.explanation: In multicellular animals, a group of similar cells alongwith intercellular substances perform a specific function. Such an organisation is called tissue. (NCERT Page 79)

questions.question: All complex animals consist of how many basic types of tissues?
questions.explanation: All complex animals consist of only four basic types of tissues - epithelial, connective, muscular and neural. (NCERT Page 79)

questions.question: The four basic types of animal tissues are:
questions.explanation: All complex animals consist of only four basic types of tissues - epithelial, connective, muscular and neural tissues. (NCERT Page 79)

questions.question: The heart consists of:
questions.explanation: Our heart consists of all the four types of tissues, i.e., epithelial, connective, muscular and neural. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The study of form or externally visible features is called:
questions.explanation: Morphology refers to study of form or externally visible features. In case of animals this refers to the external appearance of the organs or parts of the body. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The study of morphology of internal organs in animals is called:
questions.explanation: The word anatomy conventionally is used for the study of morphology of internal organs in the animals. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: Frogs belong to class:
questions.explanation: Frogs can live both on land and in freshwater and belong to class Amphibia of phylum Chordata. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The most common species of frog found in India is:
questions.explanation: The most common species of frog found in India is Rana tigrina (Indian bullfrog). (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: Animals whose body temperature varies with the temperature of the environment are called:
questions.explanation: Frogs do not have constant body temperature i.e., their body temperature varies with the temperature of the environment. Such animals are called cold blooded or poikilotherms. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The protective coloration in frogs that helps them hide from enemies is called:
questions.explanation: Frogs have the ability to change the colour to hide them from their enemies (camouflage). This protective coloration is called mimicry. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: Summer sleep in frogs is called:
questions.explanation: During peak summer frogs take shelter in deep burrows to protect them from extreme heat. This is known as summer sleep (aestivation). (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: Winter sleep in frogs is called:
questions.explanation: During peak winter frogs take shelter in deep burrows to protect them from extreme cold. This is known as winter sleep (hibernation). (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The skin of frog is smooth and slippery due to the presence of:
questions.explanation: The skin of frog is smooth and slippery due to the presence of mucus. The skin is always maintained in a moist condition. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The colour of dorsal side of frog body is generally:
options: Olive green with dark irregular spots
questions.explanation: The colour of dorsal side of body is generally olive green with dark irregular spots. On the ventral side the skin is uniformly pale yellow. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: Frog absorbs water through:
questions.explanation: The frog never drinks water but absorb it through the skin. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: Body of a frog is divisible into:
questions.explanation: Body of a frog is divisible into head and trunk. A neck and tail are absent. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The membrane that protects frog's eyes while in water is:
questions.explanation: Eyes are bulged and covered by a nictitating membrane that protects them while in water. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The membranous structure on either side of eyes in frog that receives sound signals is:
questions.explanation: On either side of eyes a membranous tympanum (ear) receives sound signals. (NCERT Page 80)

questions.question: The hind limbs of frog end in:
questions.explanation: The hind limbs end in five digits and they are larger and muscular than fore limbs that end in four digits. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: The fore limbs of frog end in:
questions.explanation: The hind limbs end in five digits and they are larger and muscular than fore limbs that end in four digits. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: Webbed digits in frog help in:
questions.explanation: Feet have webbed digits that help in swimming. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: Male frogs can be distinguished from female frogs by the presence of:
questions.explanation: Male frogs can be distinguished by the presence of sound producing vocal sacs and also a copulatory pad on the first digit of the fore limbs which are absent in female frogs. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: The copulatory pad in male frog is present on:
questions.explanation: Male frogs have a copulatory pad on the first digit of the fore limbs which are absent in female frogs. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: The alimentary canal in frog is short because frogs are:
questions.explanation: The alimentary canal is short because frogs are carnivores and hence the length of intestine is reduced. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: The correct sequence of parts in frog's alimentary canal is:
options: Mouth → Pharynx → Oesophagus → Stomach → Intestine → Rectum → Cloaca
Mouth → Oesophagus → Pharynx → Stomach → Intestine → Cloaca
Mouth → Pharynx → Stomach → Oesophagus → Intestine → Rectum → Cloaca
Mouth → Oesophagus → Stomach → Pharynx → Intestine → Cloaca
questions.explanation: The mouth opens into the buccal cavity that leads to the oesophagus through pharynx. Oesophagus opens into the stomach which continues as the intestine, rectum and finally opens outside by the cloaca. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: Bile in frog is secreted by:
questions.explanation: Liver secretes bile that is stored in the gall bladder. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: Bile is stored in:
questions.explanation: Liver secretes bile that is stored in the gall bladder. (NCERT Page 81)

questions.question: Food in frog is captured by:
questions.explanation: Food is captured by the bilobed tongue. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: Partially digested food in the stomach is called:
questions.explanation: Partially digested food called chyme is passed from stomach to the first part of the small intestine, the duodenum. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The first part of small intestine in frog is:
questions.explanation: Partially digested food called chyme is passed from stomach to the first part of the small intestine, the duodenum. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The function of bile is to:
questions.explanation: Bile emulsifies fat and pancreatic juices digest carbohydrates and proteins. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The finger-like folds in the inner wall of intestine that absorb digested food are called:
questions.explanation: Digested food is absorbed by the numerous finger-like folds in the inner wall of intestine called villi and microvilli. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: In water, skin of frog acts as:
questions.explanation: In water, skin acts as aquatic respiratory organ (cutaneous respiration). Dissolved oxygen in the water is exchanged through the skin by diffusion. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: Respiration through skin is called:
questions.explanation: In water, skin acts as aquatic respiratory organ (cutaneous respiration). (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: On land, the respiratory organs of frog are:
questions.explanation: On land, the buccal cavity, skin and lungs act as the respiratory organs. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: Respiration by lungs is called:
questions.explanation: The respiration by lungs is called pulmonary respiration. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The lungs in frog are:
options: A pair of compact solid structures
A pair of elongated, pink coloured sac-like structures
A pair of lobed structures with bronchi
questions.explanation: The lungs are a pair of elongated, pink coloured sac-like structures present in the upper part of the trunk region (thorax). (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: During aestivation and hibernation, gaseous exchange in frog takes place through:
questions.explanation: During aestivation and hibernation gaseous exchange takes place through skin. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The vascular system of frog is:
questions.explanation: The vascular system of frog is well-developed closed type. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The heart of frog has:
questions.explanation: Heart has three chambers, two atria and one ventricle and is covered by a membrane called pericardium. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The membrane covering the heart is called:
questions.explanation: Heart has three chambers, two atria and one ventricle and is covered by a membrane called pericardium. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The triangular structure that joins the right atrium in frog is:
questions.explanation: A triangular structure called sinus venosus joins the right atrium. It receives blood through the major veins called vena cava. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The ventricle of frog opens into:
questions.explanation: The ventricle opens into a sac-like conus arteriosus on the ventral side of the heart. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The special venous connection between liver and intestine in frog is called:
questions.explanation: Special venous connection between liver and intestine is present in frogs. This is called hepatic portal system. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The special venous connection between kidney and lower parts of the body in frog is called:
questions.explanation: Special venous connection between the kidney and lower parts of the body is called renal portal system. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: RBCs in frog are:
questions.explanation: RBC's are nucleated and contain red coloured pigment namely haemoglobin. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: Lymph differs from blood in that it lacks:
questions.explanation: The lymph is different from blood. It lacks few proteins and RBCs. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The excretory system of frog consists of:
options: Kidneys, ureters, cloaca and urinary bladder
questions.explanation: The excretory system consists of a pair of kidneys, ureters, cloaca and urinary bladder. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The kidneys of frog are:
options: Compact, dark red and bean like structures
questions.explanation: Kidneys are compact, dark red and bean like structures situated a little posteriorly in the body cavity on both sides of vertebral column. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The structural and functional units of kidney are called:
questions.explanation: Each kidney is composed of several structural and functional units called uriniferous tubules or nephrons. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: In male frogs, the ureters act as:
questions.explanation: Two ureters emerge from the kidneys in the male frogs. The ureters act as urinogenital duct which opens into the cloaca. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: Frog excretes:
questions.explanation: The frog excretes urea and thus is a ureotelic animal. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: Animals that excrete urea as their main nitrogenous waste are called:
questions.explanation: The frog excretes urea and thus is a ureotelic animal. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The prominent endocrine glands found in frog include:
options: Pituitary, thyroid, parathyroid, thymus, pineal body, pancreatic islets, adrenals and gonads
questions.explanation: The prominent endocrine glands found in frog are pituitary, thyroid, parathyroid, thymus, pineal body, pancreatic islets, adrenals and gonads. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The nervous system of frog is organised into:
questions.explanation: The nervous system is organised into a central nervous system (brain and spinal cord), a peripheral nervous system (cranial and spinal nerves) and an autonomic nervous system (sympathetic and parasympathetic). (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The number of pairs of cranial nerves in frog is:
questions.explanation: There are ten pairs of cranial nerves arising from the brain. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The bony structure enclosing the brain is called:
questions.explanation: Brain is enclosed in a bony structure called brain box (cranium). (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The brain of frog is divided into:
questions.explanation: The brain is divided into fore-brain, mid-brain and hind-brain. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: Forebrain of frog includes:
options: Olfactory lobes, cerebral hemispheres and diencephalon
questions.explanation: Forebrain includes olfactory lobes, paired cerebral hemispheres and unpaired diencephalon. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The midbrain of frog is characterised by:
questions.explanation: The midbrain is characterised by a pair of optic lobes. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: Hind-brain of frog consists of:
questions.explanation: Hind-brain consists of cerebellum and medulla oblongata. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The medulla oblongata passes out through:
questions.explanation: The medulla oblongata passes out through the foramen magnum and continues into spinal cord, which is enclosed in the vertebral column. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The sense organs in frog include:
options: Organs of touch, taste, smell, vision and hearing
Only organs of vision and smell
questions.explanation: Frog has different types of sense organs, namely organs of touch (sensory papillae), taste (taste buds), smell (nasal epithelium), vision (eyes) and hearing (tympanum with internal ears). (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: Eyes in frog are:
questions.explanation: Eyes in a frog are a pair of spherical structures situated in the orbit in skull. These are simple eyes (possessing only one unit). (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: External ear in frog is:
questions.explanation: External ear is absent in frogs and only tympanum can be seen externally. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The ear in frog is an organ of:
questions.explanation: The ear is an organ of hearing as well as balancing (equilibrium). (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: Male reproductive organs in frog consist of:
questions.explanation: Male reproductive organs consist of a pair of yellowish ovoid testes. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The testes in frog are attached to kidneys by:
questions.explanation: Testes are found adhered to the upper part of kidneys by a double fold of peritoneum called mesorchium. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The number of vasa efferentia arising from testes in frog is:
questions.explanation: Vasa efferentia are 10-12 in number that arise from testes. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: Vasa efferentia in male frog open into:
questions.explanation: Vasa efferentia enter the kidneys on their side and open into Bidder's canal. (NCERT Page 83)

questions.question: The cloaca is used to pass:
questions.explanation: The cloaca is a small, median chamber that is used to pass faecal matter, urine and sperms to the exterior. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: Female reproductive organs in frog include:
questions.explanation: The female reproductive organs include a pair of ovaries. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: In female frog, the ovaries have:
questions.explanation: The ovaries are situated near kidneys and there is no functional connection with kidneys. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: A mature female frog can lay approximately:
questions.explanation: A mature female can lay 2500 to 3000 ova at a time. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: Fertilisation in frog is:
questions.explanation: Fertilisation is external and takes place in water. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: The larval stage of frog is called:
questions.explanation: Development involves a larval stage called tadpole. Tadpole undergoes metamorphosis to form the adult. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: Tadpole undergoes __________ to form the adult frog.
questions.explanation: Tadpole undergoes metamorphosis to form the adult. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: Frogs are beneficial for mankind because they:
questions.explanation: Frogs are beneficial for mankind because they eat insects and protect the crop. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: Frogs maintain ecological balance because they:
options: Serve as important link of food chain and food web
questions.explanation: Frogs maintain ecological balance because these serve as an important link of food chain and food web in the ecosystem. (NCERT Page 84)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of frogs?
questions.explanation: Frogs have a three-chambered heart (two atria and one ventricle), not four-chambered. They are poikilothermic, have external fertilisation, and nucleated RBCs. (NCERT Page 82)

questions.question: The main digestive glands in frog are:
questions.explanation: The main digestive glands in frog are liver and pancreas. Liver secretes bile and pancreas produces pancreatic juice containing digestive enzymes. (NCERT Page 81-82)

questions.question: Which type of circulation is present in frog?
questions.explanation: Circulatory system in frog is closed with single circulation. (NCERT Page 84, Summary)

questions.question: In female frogs, the ureters and oviduct:
questions.explanation: In females the ureters and oviduct open seperately in the cloaca. (NCERT Page 82-83)

questions.question: The tongue of frog is:
questions.explanation: A muscular tongue is present in frog, which is bilobed at the tip and is used in capturing the prey. The tongue is attached anteriorly. (NCERT Page 84, Summary)
